Back of the napkin calcs....
If pluto's mass was entirely liquid water, the maximum energy contribution from ice formation would only be 4.36 x 10 ^27 J.
The planetary heat loss from radiation at today's low temp of 55K is 7.47 x 10^12 J/s, or the equivalent of burning 55,000 gallons of gasoline per second or the output of 74,700 one hundred megawatt power plants.
Ice fusion energy / today's heat loss rate =(4.36 x 10^27) / (7.47 x 10^12) = 5.8 x 10^14 seconds.
So 55k temp could be maintained for 18 million years.... not 4.5 billion.
So water fusion to ice could only account for less than 1/2 a percent of the heat needed to account for what is observed today.
As well, had the planet ever exceeded 70k, the huge quantities of nitrogen ice observed today would have boiled off to space owing to the tiny gravity.
